titlestmt.author: Processed by the Music Division of the Library of Congress

seriesstmt.titleproper: Guides to Special Collections in the Music Division of the Library of Congress

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2012

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: George Crumb is a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer, long-associated with the University of Pennsylvania. The collection consists of holograph manuscript scores and sketches, correspondence, business papers, and a series of meticulously assembled scrapbooks chronicling Crumb's career as a composer.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The George Crumb Papers were processed by Christopher Hartten in January 2012. Christopher Hartten coded the finding aid for EAD format in 2012.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The following Library of Congress Music Division collections contain correspondence or music by Crumb: Nicolas Slonimsky Collection (ML31.S6); Martha Graham Collection (ML31.G727); and the Moldenhaur Archives at the Library of Congress (ML31.M6). Crumb's holograph score for Ancient Voices of Children (ML29.c93 no.1 <case>) is in the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation Collection. His score for Madrigals, Books 1-2 (ML30.3c.C79 no.1 <case>) is in the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation Collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Materials from the George Crumb Papers are governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.) and other applicable international copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The George Crumb Papers are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Music Division prior to visiting in order to determine whether the desired materials will be available at that time.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], George Crumb Papers, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born, Charleston, West Virginia, to musicians George Henry Crumb, Sr. and Vivian Crumb
Began composing works "somewhat in the style of Mozart"
Attended Charleston High School
Studied piano and composition at Mason College of Music, Charleston, W. Va.
Married Elizabeth May Brown
Daughter Elizabeth Ann Crumb born
Studied composition with Eugene Weigel at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign

Studied composition with Ross Lee Finney at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. Finney emphasized meticulous notation, a characteristic evident in Crumb's works. At Michigan, he was introduced to and inspired by the poetry of Federico García Lorca, whose texts become the source for many future compositions
Studied composition with Boris Blacher at the Berlin Hochschule für Musik on a Fulbright grant

eventgrp.event: Doctorate, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. His dissertational submission, Variazioni, is not premiered until 1965
Taught piano and composition, University of Colorado, Boulder
Met pianist David Burge and composed Five Pieces for Piano, a work that earned Crumb widespread praise

chronitem.event: Son David Reed Crumb born
Began residency at the Buffalo Center for the Creative and Performing Arts

eventgrp.event: Premiere of Madrigals, Books I-II, commissioned by the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress

chronitem.event: Professor, composition, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Penn.
Composed Echoes of Time and the River
Received Pulitzer Prize for Echoes of Time and the River
Composed Night of the Four Moons, a work inspired by the Apollo 11 space flight
Completed Songs, Drones, and Refrains of Death, his first Lorca-inspired work that had been started in 1962
Premiere of Black Angels by the Stanley Quartet at the University of Michigan
Premiere of Ancient Voices of Children at the 14th Coolidge Festival of Chamber Music. The piece was commissioned by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress

First performance of Vox Balaenae by the New York Camerata at the Library of Congress. The work contained masked performers and other theatrical elements similar to Lux Aeterna, composed the previous year
Composed Makrokosmos, a cycle of four works for amplified piano
New York Philharmonic premiere of Star-Child under Pierre Boulez
PBS broadcast of Robert Mugge's film, George Crumb: Voice of the Whale
New York Philharmonic premiere of tone-poem A Haunted Landscape under Arthur Wiesberg
Served as the American representative at the Conference of the Union of Soviet Composers
Zeitgeist is premiered at the Charles Ives Festival in Duisburg, Germany
Composed Mundis Canis, a work inspired by the personalities of the Crumb family dogs.
Mundis Canis premiered by guitarist David Starobin and Crumb himself on percussion
Star-Child, recorded for the first time on Bridge Records' Complete Crumb Edition, won a Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Classical Composition
Composed the American Songbook, a cycle of six works for voice, percussion quartet, and amplified piano
Thomas Hampson performed selections from the American Songbook at the Library of Congress

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The George Crumb Papers span the period 1956 to 2011, with the majority of the materials dating from 1965 to 2003. The collection consists of holograph manuscript scores and sketches, correspondence and business papers, and a series of meticulously assembled scrapbooks chronicling Crumb's distinguished career as a composer.

The music materials represent works composed exclusively from 1959 to the present day, beginning with Crumb's Variazioni, his dissertational submission to the University of Michigan. They include inked score paste-ups for publication, pencil scores and sketches, drafts, annotated photo-reproductions, and several score transparencies. Crumb's final copy scores are inked with extraordinary precision and reflect the influence of his father's skills as a copyist and Ross Lee Finney's pedagogy. Most contain extensive patches of inked-over whiteout and pasted insertions. Notable scores include the Pulitzer Prize-winning Echoes of Time and the River, Ancient Voices of Children, Black Angels, Five Pieces for Piano, A Haunted Landscape, Lux Aeterna, Madrigals, Makrokosmos, Mundis Canis, Star-Child, and Vox Balaenae. Additionally, the collection includes several sketchbooks with materials to numerous compositions, currently identified only as volumes "A" through "C". A more comprehensive list of their contents will be available at a later time.

Business papers consist chiefly of letters, telegrams, contracts, programs, and other documents from 1956 to 2011. Included is university and publisher correspondence, student inquiries, and letters from various colleagues and friends, such as David Burge. The scrapbooks comprise seven custom bound volumes of clippings, programs, photographs, interviews, posters, and other materials that detail Crumb's musical accomplishments from roughly 1963 to 2001. These are assembled with the same meticulous care as the composer's scores and include hundreds of performance reviews from both American and international newspapers.

arrangement.head: Organization of the George Crumb Papers
arrangement.p: The George Crumb Papers are organized in three series:

scopecontent.p: Holograph manuscript scores and sketches, drafts, annotated scores, sketchbooks, and several transparencies. Final copy manuscripts contain inked-over whiteout and pasted insertions that may require special handling.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title of work. Cross references are provided for components of multi-volume works with distinctive titles, namely Makrokosmos, Images, and American Songbook.

did.unittitle: Black angels: Images I: thirteen images from the dark land: for electric string quartet, 1970
Celestial mechanics: Makrokosmos IV: cosmic dances for amplified piano, four hands, 1979
Dream sequence: Images II: for violin, cello, piano, and percussion (and offstage "glass harmonica"), 1976
Echoes of time and the river: Echoes II: four processionals for orchestra, 1967
Eine kleine Mitternachtmusik (A little midnight music): ruminations on a tune of Thelonius Monk: for amplified piano, 2001
Eleven echoes of autumn: Echoes I: for violin, alto flute, clarinet, and piano, 1965
Four nocturnes: Night music II: for violin and piano, 1964
An idyll for the misbegotten: amplified piano and percussion, 3 players, 1986
A little suite for Christmas: A.D. 1979: for piano, 1980
Makrokosmos I: twelve fantasy-pieces after the Zodiac: for amplified piano, 1972
Makrokosmos II: twelve fantasy-pieces after the Zodiac: for amplified piano, 1973

Makrokosmos III
see Music for a summer evening
Mundus canis (A dog's world): five humoresques for guitar and percussion (one player), 1997
Music for a summer evening: Makrokosmos III: for two amplified pianos and percussion (two players), 1974

Night music II
see Four nocturnes
Otherworldly resonances: six tableaux for two amplified pianos, book II, 2002
Quest: for guitar, soprano saxophone, harp, contrabass, and percussion (two players), 1990
Vox balaenae (Voice of the whale): for three masked players: electric flute, electric cello, electric piano, 1971
Zeitgeist: six tableaux for two amplified pianos, book I, 1987
Ancient voices of children: for soprano, boy soprano, oboe, mandolin, harp, electric piano (and toy piano), and percussion (three players), 1970

note.p: Commissioned by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress
Laid in: photocopied score and sketches

did.unittitle: Apparition: elegiac songs and vocalises for soprano and amplified piano (on texts from Walt Whitman's "When lilacs last in the dooryard bloom'd"), 1979
Federico's little songs for children: for soprano, flute (also piccolo, alto flute, and bass flute), and harp, 1986
A journey beyond time: American songbook II: songs of despair and hope: a cycle of Afro-American spirituals for voice, percussion quartet, and amplified piano, 2003
Lux aeterna: for five masked musicians (soprano, bass flute (and soprano recorder), sitar, and two percussionists), 1971

note.p: Books I and II only (2 scores each)
Laid in: photocopied scores and transparencies
Commissioned by the Serge Koussevitzky Music Foundation in the Library of Congress

did.unittitle: Night music I: for soprano, piano (and celesta), and percussion (two players), 1963
Night of the four moons: for alto, alto flute (doubling piccolo), banjo, electric cello, and percussion (one player), 1969
The river of life: American songbook I: songs of joy and sorrow: a cycle of hymns, spirituals, and revival tunes for voice, percussion quartet, and amplified piano, 2003
The sleeper: for mezzo-soprano and piano, 1984

Songs, drones, and refrains of death: a cycle of poems by Federico García Lorca: for baritone, electric guitar, electric contrabass, electric piano (and electric harpsichord), and percussion (two players), 1968
Star-child: a parable for soprano, antiphonal children's voices, male speaking choir (and bell ringers), and large orchestra, 1977
Unto the hills: American songbook III: songs of sadness, yearning, and innocence: a cycle of Appalachian folk songs for voice, percussion quartet, and amplified piano, 2002

scopecontent.p: Letters, telegrams, contracts, programs, royalty statements, itineraries, and other documents. Correspondence from publishers (mostly C.F. Peters), collegiate staff, and students is heavily represented. Also included are letters from various colleagues and friends, such as David Burge.
Meticulously assembled volumes of clippings, programs, photographs, and other materials.

arrangement.p: Arranged numerically by volume number. Volumes are roughly chronological in content order, but may contain miscellaneous items within several years of the dates specified.
